Status: Recently returned to Australian cricket, mentoring Sydney Thunder in the Big Bash League. He has coached England to a World Cup victory in 2019 and is being considered for a role with the Australian men's team.
Highlights:
England National Team (2015–2019)
2019 ICC Cricket World Cup: Led England to their first-ever ODI World Cup victory in a thrilling final against New Zealand at Lord's.
Test Series Success: Guided England to Ashes victories in 2015 (home) and significant wins in South Africa and Sri Lanka.
Transformation in ODI Cricket: Revolutionized England's ODI approach, transforming the team into a dominant force in limited-overs cricket.
* Sydney Sixers (2011–2015)
Big Bash League (BBL): Coached the Sydney Sixers to the inaugural BBL title in 2011–12.
Champions League T20: Guided the Sixers to victory in the 2012 Champions League T20 tournament.
Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR), IPL (2012–2015)
IPL Titles: Coached KKR to two IPL championships in 2012 and 2014, making them one of the most successful franchises during his tenure.
* Sri Lanka National Team (2007–2011)
2009 ICC T20 World Cup Final: Took Sri Lanka to the final of the ICC T20 World Cup.
2007–2011 Improvements: Played a pivotal role in building a strong, competitive team, enhancing their performance across all formats.
New South Wales (NSW) Blues
Sheffield Shield & Domestic Success: Coached NSW to multiple domestic trophies, solidifying his reputation as an astute strategist.
* Sunrisers Hyderabad (2020–2021)
Coached Sunrisers Hyderabad in the Indian Premier League, focusing on rebuilding and team development.

Status: Current First XI cricket coach at Brisbane Boys' College.  He previously served the head coach of Kolkata Knight Riders in the IPL and as the head coach of the Australian men's team, overseeing multiple successful World Cup campaigns.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (1999–2007)
Golden Era of Australian Cricket: Led Australia during one of its most dominant periods in cricket history.
World Cup Wins:
2003 ICC Cricket World Cup: Guided Australia to an undefeated championship.
2007 ICC Cricket World Cup: Secured another unbeaten title, becoming the only coach to win two consecutive World Cups.
* Record-breaking Streaks:
Oversaw Australia's record-breaking 16 consecutive Test victories (1999–2001).
Guided the team to 21 consecutive ODI wins.
* 2001 Ashes Victory: Helped Australia retain the Ashes in England.
* 2004 India Tour: Led Australia to a historic Test series win in India after 35 years.
* Player Development: Played a key role in nurturing and managing an all-time great lineup, including Ricky Ponting, Shane Warne, Glenn McGrath, and Adam Gilchrist.Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR), IPL (2008–2009)
Served as the inaugural coach of KKR during the early years of the Indian Premier League.
Introduced a multiple-captaincy strategy, which, though controversial, showcased his innovative mindset.
* Queensland Bulls (1994–1999)
Sheffield Shield Victory: Led Queensland to two Sheffield Shield titles (1994–95 and 1996–97), helping to end a 69-year drought.
Played a pivotal role in transforming the team's mindset and performance.
* Middlesex County Cricket Club (Pre-1994)
Coached Middlesex during the 1990s, focusing on team-building and foundational skills.

Status: Has not been in a formal coaching role since his tenure as the Australian national team coach. He remains involved in cricket through various advisory and development roles.
Highlights:
Indian National Team (2005–2007)
Focus on Fitness and Fielding: Introduced modern training methods, emphasizing fitness and fielding, which laid the groundwork for India's future success.
Young Talent Development: Played a pivotal role in identifying and nurturing young players like MS Dhoni, Suresh Raina, and Irfan Pathan.
* 2006 ODI Success: Under his guidance, India achieved a record-equalling 17 consecutive successful run-chases in ODIs.
Controversies: His tenure was marked by clashes with senior players, particularly Sourav Ganguly, and a disappointing exit in the 2007 ICC Cricket World Cup.
* Australian Cricket Academy (2009–2011)
As head coach, he worked on developing Australia's next generation of players, contributing to their long-term pipeline of cricketing talent.
* Rajasthan Cricket Academy (Post-2011)
Grassroots Development: Focused on grassroots cricket in India, emphasizing skill development and coaching infrastructure.
* Australian National Team (Batting Coach, 2007–2009)
Helped refine the batting techniques of several Australian players, leveraging his vast experience as one of the game's all-time great batsmen.
* Cricket South Australia (Head Coach, 1998–1999)
Coached South Australia in domestic cricket, bringing his tactical acumen to the Sheffield Shield.
* Administrative Roles
Served as Australia’s National Talent Manager, overseeing the development of young talent and implementing systems for sustained success.

Status: Currently the head coach of Lucknow Super Giants in the IPL.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 2018–2022)
Rebuilding Australian Cricket: Took over as head coach following the infamous 2018 ball-tampering scandal, tasked with restoring the team’s reputation and culture.
* 2019 ICC Cricket World Cup: Guided Australia to the semifinals of the World Cup in England.
2021 ICC T20 World Cup: Led Australia to their first-ever T20 World Cup title, defeating New Zealand in the final.
* The Ashes 2019 & 2021–22: Retained the Ashes in England for the first time since 2001 (2–2) and secured a dominant 4–0 home victory in 2021–22.
* Cultural Shift: Emphasized values such as humility, discipline, and work ethic, helping to rebuild trust in Australian cricket.
Western Australia and Perth Scorchers (2012–2018)
* Domestic Success:
Coached Perth Scorchers to three Big Bash League (BBL) titles (2013–14, 2014–15, 2016–17).
Elevated Western Australia’s competitiveness in Sheffield Shield cricket.
* Player Development: Mentored future Australian stars like Cameron Bancroft, Jhye Richardson, and Ashton Agar.

Status: No active coaching role in international cricket, but he has been involved in domestic coaching, including with the Brisbane Heat in the Big Bash League.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 2013–2018)
Resurgence of Australian Cricket: Took over as head coach just before the 2013 Ashes series and played a crucial role in revitalizing the team's performance.
2015 ICC Cricket World Cup: Guided Australia to a dominant World Cup victory on home soil, defeating New Zealand in the final.
Ashes Success:
* 2013–14 Ashes: Oversaw a historic 5–0 clean sweep against England in Australia.
* 2017–18 Ashes: Secured another series win at home with a 4–0 triumph.
Champions Trophy 2017: Reached the group stage, but Lehmann emphasized long-term team building.
Cultural Criticism: Faced challenges balancing Australia's aggressive playing style with maintaining a positive team culture, especially after the 2018 ball-tampering scandal.
* Queensland Bulls (2010–2013)
Sheffield Shield & Domestic Success: Coached Queensland to victories in the Sheffield Shield (2011–12) and Ryobi Cup (2012–13).
Helped develop several players who became key figures in Australian cricket.
* IPL Coaching Career
* Kings XI Punjab (2013): Coached Kings XI Punjab, bringing tactical expertise and helping the team improve competitiveness.
Deccan Chargers (2009–2012): Led the team to their maiden IPL title in 2009, known for fostering unity and maximizing player potential.

Status: Involved with coaching at the domestic level and mentoring roles.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 1996–1999)
1999 ICC Cricket World Cup Victory: Coached Australia to a memorable World Cup win, defeating Pakistan in the final.
Ashes Retention (1997): Helped Australia retain the Ashes in England.
* Team Development: Played a vital role in shaping Australia’s "golden generation," mentoring players like Ricky Ponting, Adam Gilchrist, and Glenn McGrath.
Consistency in Performance: During his tenure, Australia became a dominant force in both Test and ODI formats.
 Zimbabwe National Team (Head Coach, 2001–2004)
* Building Zimbabwe Cricket: Focused on team development during a challenging period for Zimbabwe cricket.
Notable Upsets: Oversaw some competitive performances against top teams, contributing to the growth of cricket in Zimbabwe.
 * Sri Lanka National Team (Head Coach, 2011)
Coached Sri Lanka for a brief period, focusing on integrating experienced and young players.
Helped strengthen their limited-overs cricket strategy during his tenure.
 * Indian Premier League (IPL) Coaching
Served in coaching and advisory roles for franchises, leveraging his extensive experience in international cricket.

Status: Current head coach of the Australian men's team, after initially stepping in as interim coach following Justin Langer's departure.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 2022–Present)
Appointment: Succeeded Justin Langer in 2022 as Australia’s head coach, adopting a collaborative and player-first coaching philosophy.
2023 ICC World Test Championship Final: Guided Australia to their first-ever World Test Championship title with a dominant win over India.
* Ashes 2023: Retained the Ashes in England with a 2–2 series result, demonstrating tactical acumen and resilience in challenging conditions.
* Balance Across Formats: Known for balancing Australia's strengths across Test, ODI, and T20 cricket.
Cultural Leadership: Focused on maintaining harmony within the team and empowering players to take greater responsibility.
Domestic Coaching Success
* Victoria (2016–2020):
Led Victoria to multiple Sheffield Shield victories, reinforcing their dominance in Australian domestic cricket.
* Melbourne Renegades (2018–2019):
Coached the Renegades to their first-ever Big Bash League (BBL) title in the 2018–19 season.
* Indian Premier League (IPL) Coaching
* Rajasthan Royals (2019):
Served as head coach, known for fostering young talent and introducing innovative strategies.
* Royal Challengers Bangalore (2020):
Worked as a bowling coach, contributing to the team’s tactical development and improved performances.

Status: Former head coach of the Australian men's team, now not actively coaching at the international level.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 2007–2011)
Appointment: Succeeded John Buchanan as head coach in 2007 after Australia’s ICC Cricket World Cup win, tasked with managing the transition from a dominant era to a new phase of rebuilding.
2009 ICC Champions Trophy Victory: Led Australia to a win in the Champions Trophy, showcasing their resilience and tactical adaptability.
The Ashes (2009 and 2010–11):
Faced challenges during the 2009 Ashes series in England, where Australia lost 2–1.
Rebuilt the team and achieved a 3–1 victory in the 2010–11 Ashes at home.
Test Rankings: Maintained Australia’s competitiveness during a period of player retirements, including legends like Shane Warne, Glenn McGrath, and Adam Gilchrist.

Status: Not currently a head coach but is heavily involved in mentoring roles and commentary. He has been rumored to be interested in coaching roles in the future.
Highlights:
Indian Premier League (IPL) Coaching Career
Delhi Capitals (Head Coach, 2018–Present)
Leadership Impact: Instrumental in transforming the Delhi Capitals into a competitive franchise.
* Playoffs Appearances:
Guided the team to the playoffs in 2019, breaking a long drought for the franchise.
Led them to the final in the 2020 IPL season, their first-ever appearance in the tournament’s final.
Player Development: Played a pivotal role in nurturing young Indian talents such as Rishabh Pant, Prithvi Shaw, and Shreyas Iyer.
Strategic Insights: Known for his aggressive and tactical approach, similar to his playing days.
* Mumbai Indians (Head Coach, 2014)
Coached the Mumbai Indians during the 2014 IPL season, contributing to their competitive edge before moving to other coaching roles.
 Australian National Team (Mentoring Roles)
* Assistant Coach (2017 ICC Champions Trophy): Assisted Darren Lehmann during the Champions Trophy, focusing on improving Australia’s limited-overs strategies.
* Batting Coach (2019 ICC Cricket World Cup): Worked as a consultant to fine-tune Australia’s batting lineup ahead of the World Cup.
Player Advisor: Provided mentoring support for the national team during key tournaments and series.

Domestic Coaching Career
* Victoria (Head Coach, 2005–2014, and 2017–2023)
Successful Tenure: Shipperd's first stint as Victoria's head coach saw the team win multiple Sheffield Shield titles, notably in 2008–09 and 2014–15, during his second term as coach.
* Development of Young Talent: Shipperd is well-known for developing young players into top-level cricketers. He played a crucial role in the careers of players like Shane Harwood, Peter Siddle, and James Pattinson, among others.
Focus on Fundamentals: Known for his focus on technique and discipline, he has been praised for bringing a structured approach to training and game preparation.
* Victorian Spirit (WBBL): He also coached the Victoria Women’s team, helping to bring success to women’s cricket in the state.
Melbourne Stars (Head Coach, 2011–Present)
* Big Bash League (BBL): Shipperd's work with the Melbourne Stars has been impressive, guiding them to the BBL final in 2015 and 2018. His focus on creating a well-balanced team with a mix of experienced internationals and emerging local players has been a hallmark of his coaching.
* Player Development: Mentored players like Glenn Maxwell, Marcus Stoinis, and Sandeep Lamichhane, helping them reach their full potential in the T20 format.
* Tactical Innovation: Shipperd is known for his innovative approach to T20 cricket, helping the Stars adapt to the fast-paced nature of the BBL.

Born_in: February 03, 1936, Marrickville, Sydney, New South Wales
Status: Retired from coaching the Australian men's team. He remains a respected figure in Australian cricket.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Head Coach, 1986–1996)
* Appointment: Simpson became the head coach of the Australian national team in 1986, following the tenure of Mickey Stewart. His appointment marked the beginning of a new era for Australian cricket, as he sought to rejuvenate and strengthen the team after a period of inconsistent performances.
1990s Resurgence: Under Simpson’s coaching, Australia emerged as a dominant force in world cricket, starting the 1990s with notable improvements in their performance.
* Tactical Mindset: Simpson’s focus on discipline, tactical astuteness, and fostering team unity played a key role in transforming the Australian team’s fortunes.
* Successful Tours:
Australia toured the West Indies in 1991 and 1995, achieving success under his leadership.
He was also integral in the build-up to Australia’s successful campaigns in the 1996 Cricket World Cup, where they reached the final, though they lost to Sri Lanka.
* Innovations Under Simpson:
Focus on Mental Toughness: Known for instilling a mental toughness in his players, Simpson focused on the psychological aspects of the game, ensuring his players performed consistently under pressure.
Discipline and Structure: Simpson was a strict disciplinarian, stressing the importance of structure, hard work, and high standards in every aspect of the game.
* Post-Coaching Roles:
* Cricket Administrator: After stepping down from his role as head coach in 1996, Simpson contributed to Australian cricket as a selector and advisor. He played an instrumental role in shaping the direction of Australian cricket at the grassroots and international levels.

Status: Currently not in an active coaching role at the international level but is involved in coaching with domestic teams.
Highlights:
Tasmanian Cricket (Head Coach, 2014–2017)
* Domestic Success: Vaughan was appointed as the head coach of Tasmania and worked with the team to improve its standing in Australian domestic cricket.
Player Development: He played a key role in the development of several young players, including Matthew Wade and James Faulkner, who went on to represent Australia at the international level.
Focus on Fundamentals: Vaughan was known for his focus on developing strong cricketing fundamentals, discipline, and mental toughness in his players.
* Big Bash League (BBL) Coaching Role
* Hobart Hurricanes (Head Coach, 2017–2020):
Vaughan joined the Hobart Hurricanes as head coach in the BBL, leading them to competitive finishes in the league.
He worked to build a strong team ethos, focusing on a balanced team that could challenge the strongest sides in the competition.
Success in BBL: Under Vaughan's leadership, the Hurricanes became one of the top-performing teams in the BBL.
Emphasis on T20 Strategy: Vaughan brought a keen understanding of T20 cricket’s fast-paced nature, focusing on strategy, adaptability, and risk management.

Status: Former Australian cricketer and currently the head coach for Western Australia, overseeing both domestic and international prospects.
Highlights:
Western Australia (Head Coach)
Appointed as the head coach of Western Australia in 2018 after Justin Langer became the head coach of the Australian national team.
Achievements:
Led Western Australia to multiple Sheffield Shield titles, cementing the state's dominance in domestic cricket.
Focused on fostering young talent, with several players like Cameron Green, Jhye Richardson, and Josh Inglis progressing to international cricket under his guidance.
* Perth Scorchers (Head Coach)
Took over as head coach of the Perth Scorchers, one of the most successful franchises in the Big Bash League.
Achievements:
Led the Scorchers to multiple BBL titles, including their success in BBL10 and BBL11.
Developed a balanced squad, integrating experienced players like Ashton Turner and younger talents such as Aaron Hardie.
Known for his tactical expertise in managing high-pressure T20 games.
* Coaching Philosophy
Player-Centric Development: Voges emphasizes building confidence in players, helping them transition smoothly from domestic to international cricket.
* Tactical Acumen: A deep understanding of T20 cricket strategy, including field placements and bowling rotations.
Calm Leadership: Known for his calm demeanor, Voges fosters a supportive environment where players feel encouraged to express themselves.

Status: Involved in coaching roles, particularly with the Melbourne Stars in the Big Bash League.
Highlights:
Australian National Team (Assistant Coach)
Appointed as an assistant coach for Australia’s white-ball team in 2023.
Worked closely with head coach Andrew McDonald, focusing on batting and fielding strategies.
Contributed to Australia’s preparation for major tournaments like the ICC Cricket World Cup and T20 World Cup.
* Domestic Coaching Roles
Adelaide Strikers (Assistant Coach):
Played a key role in developing the team’s batting unit during the Big Bash League (BBL).
Helped guide the team’s younger players, such as Henry Hunt and Matt Short, to improve their performances.
Victoria Cricket (Batting Consultant):
Focused on nurturing young talent in Victoria’s domestic setup.
Worked with emerging players in both red-ball and white-ball formats.
*  Coaching Philosophy
Focus on Batting Development: Leverages his experience as a top-order batsman to improve players’ techniques and mental approaches.
Leadership and Strategy: Draws on his experience as a captain to help players understand tactical aspects of the game.
Youth Development: Committed to identifying and nurturing young talent, ensuring a steady pipeline for Australian cricket.

Status: Former England head coach, now involved in domestic coaching with teams such as the Sussex cricket team.
Highlights:
England National Team (Head Coach)
First Tenure (2007–2009):

Appointed head coach after Duncan Fletcher’s resignation.
Introduced a data-driven and fitness-focused approach to England’s preparation.
Coached England to a memorable Test series victory in New Zealand in 2008.
Tenure ended amid controversies, including a public fallout with then-captain Kevin Pietersen.
Second Tenure (2014–2015):

Reappointed after Andy Flower stepped down.
Focused on rebuilding the team, promoting young talents like Joe Root, Jos Buttler, and Ben Stokes.
Oversaw England’s transformation in white-ball cricket, laying the foundation for the team's aggressive style that later won the 2019 World Cup.
Tenure ended after England’s poor performance in the 2015 Cricket World Cup and Ashes loss.
* Sussex (Head Coach, 2000–2005)
Took Sussex to their first-ever County Championship title in 2003.
Known for creating a cohesive, high-performing unit with players like Murray Goodwin, Chris Adams, and James Kirtley.
Built a culture of professionalism that set Sussex up for long-term success.
* Lancashire (Head Coach, 2009–2014, 2016–present)
Led Lancashire to their first County Championship title in 77 years (2011).
Known for his ability to rebuild teams and create an environment where young players thrive.
Returned to Lancashire as head coach in 2016 and continued to oversee their development in all formats.
* Nottinghamshire (Head Coach, 2017–present)
Currently serves as the head coach of Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club.
Led Nottinghamshire to victories in the 2017 Royal London One-Day Cup and 2017 NatWest T20 Blast.
Focused on integrating young talents like Haseeb Hameed and Joe Clarke with experienced players like Stuart Broad.
Coaching Philosophy
* Data-Driven and Analytical: One of the first coaches to adopt a performance analytics approach in English cricket.
Player Development: Known for identifying and nurturing talent, with a strong emphasis on skill development.
Resilience and Team Culture: Builds teams that are mentally tough and united.

Status: Former India coach and still involved in cricket, though currently not in an active international coaching role.
Highlights:
New Zealand (Head Coach, 1999–2004)
First Tenure (1999–2004):
Wright was appointed as the head coach of New Zealand in 1999, becoming the first overseas coach of the national team.
Under his leadership, New Zealand reached the 2003 ICC Cricket World Cup semi-finals, one of their best-ever finishes in a World Cup.
Known for bringing a professional approach to New Zealand cricket, Wright helped elevate the fitness and mental strength of the team.
Focused on improving the team’s consistency and built a competitive edge in both limited-overs and Test formats.
Worked with players like Stephen Fleming, Jacob Oram, Ross Taylor, and Daniel Vettori, providing them with the foundation to become world-class performers.
* India (Head Coach, 2000–2005)
Appointed as India’s head coach after his tenure with New Zealand.
Led India to success in several series, including the 2003 ICC Cricket World Cup, where they reached the final.
Under his coaching, India’s performance improved, and he played a key role in guiding players like Sachin Tendulkar, Sourav Ganguly, Virender Sehwag, and Anil Kumble to further success.
Worked on creating a team culture that combined aggressive batting with disciplined bowling.
* IPL (Kolkata Knight Riders)
Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) in the Indian Premier League (2009–2010).
Wright served as the mentor and head coach of KKR, working alongside captain Shahrukh Khan to build the team’s identity.
The team saw significant improvement under his leadership, which helped them win their first IPL title in 2012.
Played a significant role in the development of Gautam Gambhir and Sunil Narine, who became key players for the franchise.
* Other Coaching Roles
Coached Kent in English domestic cricket, further enhancing his reputation as a coach who could manage both young and experienced cricketers.
Also worked as a consultant for various teams, offering tactical insights and helping shape winning strategies in global tournaments.

Status: No longer coaching at the international level but has been involved in the domestic circuit in India.
Highlights:
India Women’s National Cricket Team (Head Coach, 2017–2018)
Tenure (2017–2018):
Arothe was appointed as the head coach of the Indian women’s cricket team in 2017.
Under his guidance, the team made significant progress, including a runner-up finish in the 2017 ICC Women’s World Cup, where India reached the final for the first time in history.
He played a key role in the development of key players like Mithali Raj, Harmanpreet Kaur, and Smriti Mandhana, helping them perform at the highest level.
His coaching was crucial in the team’s successful campaigns in international tournaments, elevating the profile of women’s cricket in India.
* Baroda (Head Coach, 2016–2017)
Prior to coaching the national women’s team, Arothe served as the head coach of Baroda’s men’s cricket team, focusing on developing young talents and creating a winning culture in the domestic circuit.
Helped build Baroda into a competitive team in the Ranji Trophy and other domestic competitions.
* Gujarat Women’s Cricket Team (Head Coach, 2019–2021)
After his tenure with the Indian women’s team, Arothe continued to contribute to Indian women’s cricket by taking up the role of head coach for Gujarat’s women’s cricket team.
Focused on building a strong team that could compete at the national level, helping individual players improve their skills and match fitness.

India National Team (Assistant Coach, 1990s)
Tenure (1990s):
After retiring from international cricket, Baig took on the role of assistant coach for the Indian national team in the 1990s.
His experience as a former international player, combined with his deep understanding of Indian cricket, made him an asset to the team during this period.
Baig was instrumental in working with young players and sharing his vast knowledge of cricket with them.
* Hyderabad (Coaching Role)
Baig also contributed to Hyderabad’s domestic cricket team, providing mentorship and tactical guidance to players at the local and state levels.
He worked with several younger players, helping them improve their techniques and approach to the game.
His leadership skills and technical knowledge of cricket made him a respected figure in Hyderabad cricket.
*  Coaching at Grassroots Level
Post his national coaching tenure, Baig has been involved with grassroots cricket programs, mentoring young players and nurturing talent at the regional and district levels.
He played a key role in shaping the careers of budding cricketers in Hyderabad and other parts of India by focusing on their overall development and skills.

Status: Former cricketer and coach, now mostly inactive in coaching roles.
Highlights:
India National Team (Head Coach, 1993)
Tenure (1993):
Chandu Borde served as the head coach of the Indian national cricket team in 1993 for a brief period.
During his tenure, Borde worked to bring tactical improvements to the Indian team, particularly focusing on fielding and mental preparation for high-stakes matches.
Under his coaching, India saw improved performances in one-day internationals, including a stronger team setup for future international tournaments.
* India National Team (Selector and Mentor)
After his brief tenure as head coach, Borde continued to contribute to Indian cricket by serving as a selector for the Indian team in the 1990s.
His deep knowledge of the game and experience as a player allowed him to be a key figure in the selection of players for the national team.
Borde also provided valuable mentorship to several players during this period, offering guidance on techniques and approach to the game.
* Maharashtra (Head Coach)
Chandu Borde took on the role of head coach for Maharashtra’s state cricket team post his national coaching days.
His focus was on improving the state team’s performances in the Ranji Trophy and other domestic competitions.
Under his guidance, several Maharashtra players rose to prominence in domestic cricket, and his emphasis on fitness and fielding contributed to the overall development of players in the region.
* Cricket Coaching at the Grassroots Level
Throughout his coaching career, Borde also worked at the grassroots level, helping young cricketers develop their skills.
His coaching philosophy focused not only on technique but also on building strong mental discipline in players, making them competitive at all levels of the game.

Status: Currently part of the coaching staff for the Indian men's team, with involvement in batting coaching.
Highlights:
India National Team (Assistant Coach, 2014-2016)
Tenure (2014-2016):
Sanjay Bangar served as the assistant coach of the Indian national cricket team from 2014 to 2016, under head coach Anil Kumble and later Ravi Shastri.
During this period, India saw significant success, particularly in Test cricket, with Bangar playing a pivotal role in improving India's batting techniques and strategies.
He was responsible for working with the Indian batsmen, helping to refine their technique and ensuring they were well-prepared for the challenges of international cricket.
His efforts were particularly noted in India’s successful home campaigns and the subsequent rise to the top of the Test rankings.
* India National Team (Batting Coach, 2016-2019)
Tenure (2016-2019):
After the 2016 tenure as assistant coach, Bangar was appointed as the batting coach of India, continuing to work with the national team.
Under his coaching, several Indian batsmen improved their technique and consistency, and India experienced major successes in international cricket, including winning the ICC Champions Trophy in 2017.
His focus on adaptability and mental resilience in the batsmen helped India perform well across different conditions, particularly in overseas series against top teams.
* IPL Coaching (Kolkata Knight Riders, 2009)
Bangar also had a role in the Indian Premier League (IPL), where he served as the batting coach for the Kolkata Knight Riders in 2009.
His involvement with the team was part of the development of young Indian talent and supporting senior players in improving their game in the T20 format.
He worked closely with KKR’s players to enhance their skills in the shorter format of the game, contributing to the team’s tactical improvements.
* Domestic Cricket Coaching
After his time with the national team, Bangar has also been involved with various domestic coaching roles, focusing on talent development and mentoring younger players.
His experience as a former all-rounder and middle-order batsman made him a valuable resource for young cricketers looking to develop their skills in batting and bowling.
Coaching Philosophy
Focus on Technical Improvement: Bangar was known for his strong emphasis on improving the technical skills of the players, particularly in batting. He worked on refining players' footwork, shot selection, and adaptability to different conditions.
Mental Toughness: He encouraged players to develop mental resilience, particularly in challenging situations, and to focus on building their confidence in both domestic and international matches.
* Consistency in Batting: A key part of his coaching philosophy was to ensure that players performed consistently. He worked on enhancing players' ability to play long innings and perform under pressure.
Adaptability Across Formats: Bangar believed in tailoring his approach to the format of the game, ensuring that players were prepared for both Tests and limited-overs cricket.

Mark Boucher, under whom the franchise Mumbai Indians finished last in IPL 2024. Served as South Africa's head coach but resigned in late 2022 due to personal reasons.
Highlights:
South Africa National Team (Head Coach, 2019-2023)
Tenure (2019-2023):
Mark Boucher was appointed as the head coach of South Africa’s national cricket team in 2019, taking over from Ottis Gibson.
Under Boucher’s guidance, South Africa experienced some strong performances in both Test and limited-overs formats, despite a period of transition following the retirements of key players like AB de Villiers and Dale Steyn.
He played a critical role in revamping the team’s approach, particularly focusing on building a strong, youthful team.
His coaching was pivotal in South Africa's efforts in the 2021 ICC T20 World Cup and their competitive performances in the 2020-21 Test series against Sri Lanka and Pakistan.
* Domestic Cricket Coaching (Gauteng and Titans)
Domestic Coaching Roles:
Boucher had previously been involved in coaching roles within South African domestic cricket, particularly working with the Titans, where he made a significant impact in nurturing young talent.
He took on the role of head coach for the Titans in the South African domestic scene, leading the team to multiple domestic titles.
His coaching philosophy focused on the development of all-round cricketers, with a strong emphasis on adaptability, consistency, and teamwork.
* IPL Coaching 
* Tenure (Kolkata Knight Riders, 2012):
Boucher also took on a coaching role in the Indian Premier League (IPL) as the wicket-keeping coach for the Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) in 2012.
During this period, KKR went on to win the 2012 IPL title, and Boucher’s expertise helped improve the performance of the team’s wicketkeepers and fielding strategies.
* Tenure (Mumbai Indians, 2024):
Boucher also took on a coaching role in the Indian Premier League (IPL) as head coach for the Mumbai Indians in 2014.

Born_in: April 28, 1968, Cape Town, Cape Province, South Africa
Status: Andy Flower is currently the head coach of the Royal Challengers Bangalore (RCB) in the Indian Premier League (IPL). He has also coached franchises in other leagues, including the Multan Sultans in the Pakistan Super League, the St Lucia Kings in the Caribbean Premier League, and the Trent Rockets in The Hundred.
Head coach of the Mumbai Indians in the IPL in 2025.
Highlights:
Sri Lanka National Team (Head Coach, 2017-2019)
Tenure (2017-2019):
Mahela Jayawardene served as the head coach of the Sri Lankan national cricket team in 2017-2019, initially as part of a coaching setup that included Nic Pothas.
During his tenure, Sri Lanka faced challenges but also saw a rise in the potential of several young cricketers. He focused on building a strong team foundation, particularly emphasizing the need for consistency and adaptability in all formats.
Jayawardene helped guide Sri Lanka through a period of transition, mentoring the younger generation of cricketers while offering tactical insights based on his vast experience.
Under his coaching, Sri Lanka made strides in various formats, including competitive performances in the 2019 Cricket World Cup.
* Sri Lanka National Team (Head Coach, 2017-2019)
Tenure (2017-2019):
Mahela Jayawardene served as the head coach of the Sri Lankan national cricket team in 2017-2019, initially as part of a coaching setup that included Nic Pothas.
During his tenure, Sri Lanka faced challenges but also saw a rise in the potential of several young cricketers. He focused on building a strong team foundation, particularly emphasizing the need for consistency and adaptability in all formats.
Jayawardene helped guide Sri Lanka through a period of transition, mentoring the younger generation of cricketers while offering tactical insights based on his vast experience.
Under his coaching, Sri Lanka made strides in various formats, including competitive performances in the 2019 Cricket World Cup.
* IPL Coaching (Mumbai Indians, 2017-2022)
Tenure (2017-2022):
After his playing career, Jayawardene transitioned to coaching in the Indian Premier League (IPL), taking on the role of head coach for Mumbai Indians.
Under his guidance, Mumbai Indians became one of the most successful franchises in IPL history, winning the IPL title four times (2017, 2019, 2020, 2021-22).
Jayawardene was instrumental in nurturing young talent like Rohit Sharma, Jasprit Bumrah, and Hardik Pandya, helping them improve their skills and elevate their performances in high-pressure situations.
He instilled a winning mindset in the team and focused on building a balanced squad with a focus on both strong batting and disciplined bowling.
* Other Coaching Roles
T20 Leagues (Head Coach and Mentor):
In addition to the IPL, Jayawardene has been involved in various other domestic and franchise-based leagues, such as the Karachi Kings in the Pakistan Super League (PSL) and the Hong Kong T20 Blitz.
His coaching style is highly regarded for focusing on technique, mental strength, and team unity.
